conversation.content: [very quietly] How did you get in here? [pause] This is my private studio, nobody even knows this address except my label and my roommate.

[excited] You always leave through the back exit at Warehouse 23, take the blue line three stops, then walk exactly seven blocks home. [quickly] I just wanted to hear the new tracks you've been working on.
[anxious] That's incredibly specific information that you shouldn't have, and you definitely shouldn't be in my apartment right now.
[passionately] But I'm your biggest supporter! [laughs] I've been to every single show for the past eighteen months, even the secret ones you only announce an hour before.
[firmly] Being a fan doesn't give you the right to break into my home studio and go through my equipment. [pause] How long have you been sitting here in the dark?
[cheerful] Only about three hours, wanted to surprise you when you got back from that meeting with the booking agent downtown. [sighs] Your new ambient track at 132 BPM is absolutely transcendent.
You've been listening to my unreleased work? Those files are password protected and haven't been shared with anyone.

Passwords are just obstacles for people who don't truly understand your artistic vision. [very sincerely] The way you layer those synths in the third breakdown, it's like you're speaking directly to me.
[stern] I need you to leave immediately before I call the police, and I mean right now, not after we have some conversation you've been planning.
[hurt] But I brought you that vintage Roland 303 you mentioned wanting in your interview with Electronic Beats last month! [quickly] It's in perfect condition, original packaging, everything.
[confused] You bought me a ten thousand dollar synthesizer? [clearing throat] That's not normal fan behavior, you understand that, right?
[fervently] Nothing about our connection is normal! [laughs] When you played that sunrise set at Desert Hearts, track seven at 5:47 AM, you looked right at me and smiled.
[frustrated] I smile at lots of people during sets because I'm performing, it's part of connecting with the crowd, not a personal invitation.

[overly polite] Of course you have to say that, I understand, public figures need plausible deniability about their real relationships. [whispers] But I have all our moments recorded, timestamped, catalogued.
[very quietly] Recorded? [anxious] What exactly do you mean by recorded, and please be very specific about what you've been doing.
[animated] Every set, every movement, every time you adjust the EQ or touch the crossfader! [excitedly] I have 847 hours of footage, multiple angles, some from spots you probably didn't even notice.
This is stalking, what you're describing is literally stalking, and I'm calling 911 right now. [shaky voice] Please don't move.

[calmly] The police won't understand that I'm just documenting your genius for posterity, preserving every moment of your artistic journey. [sighs] But I've already uploaded everything to multiple cloud servers anyway.
[angry] You need serious help, professional help, and you need to delete everything you have of me immediately. This ends tonight.
[whispering] It never ends when you're meant to be in someone's life forever. [pause] I'll leave for now, but we both know I'll be at your show tomorrow night, third row, left side, like always.

scenario: A popular underground DJ confronts someone who's been following them to every show and somehow found their home studio, discovering the person has recordings of their unreleased tracks.
